Mindoraan, pah ok middovahhe lahvraan til. As you know, all his dragon-loyalists (are) mustered there. (Odahviing, 00048F05)
Can only reference dragons. See Grah-Zeymahzin ‘ally’ for a more general word.
n. loyalty; oath, vow; sworn word
Alduin sizaan midroti. Alduin has lost my loyalty. (Odahviing, 000E16FE)
Etymology suggests sworn loyalty, loyalty as given by an oath.

Het ont kriist Miraak, wo ahtiid ok sahvot ol Qah, spaan naal Deyra fah ok unslaad midun. Here once stood Miraak, who wore his faith as Armor, shielded by the Daedra for his unending loyalty. (Word Wall for Qah, Dragon Aspect)
More general than synonym midrot, which refers to loyalty specifically given by word or vow.

Wulfin wahlaan qethsegol judii vahrukt Hrefna Ruvaak-Om wen miin diin sos do naan jul. Wulfik raised this stone in memory of his queen, Hrefna Raven-Hair, whose eyes could Freeze the blood of any man. (Word Wall for Diin, Frost Breath)
Possibly related to miiraad ‘doorway’, miiraak ‘portal’ (compare window from Old Norse vind-auga ‘wind-eye’).
n. door, doorway; opening, path, option, opportunity
Onikaan koraav gein miraad [sic]. Wisdom sees the one doorway. (Odahviing, 0004DE40)
Het ont kriist Fiik do Amusan, miiraad wah hahvulon ahrk miiraak do hahnu. Here once stood the Mirror of Amusan, doorway to nightmares and portal of dreams. (Unused Word Wall for Fiik, Phantom Form)
Given dragons’ limited experience with doorways, may be a much broader word that refers to any opening, metaphorically an option or opportunity.
Related to miiraak ‘portal’ (and possibly to miin ‘eye’; compare window from Old Norse vind-auga ‘wind-eye’). Might also be connected to Ayleidoon mitta ‘enter’.
Spelt miiraad in the dictionary on PrimaGames.com, miraad in the in-game dialogue.
Zu'u uth nall [sic] thurri dein daar miiraak. I (was) ordered by my lord to keep/guard this portal. (Nahkriin, 000E16FA)

Related to miiraad ‘doorway’ (and possibly to miin ‘eye’; compare window from Old Norse vind-auga ‘wind-eye’). May also relate to aak ‘guide’, in the sense of something that leads somewhere. Possibly connected to Ayleidoon mitta ‘enter’.
Not to be confused for the dragon priest name Miraak ‘allegiance-guide’.

Het mah Arnvid faal Staadnau, wen Haas denos mindin Kein do Galik, kolos rok ofaal dilos ahraan. Here fell Arnvid the Unbound, whose Health declined after the War of Pines, in which he received a deadly wound. (Word Wall for Haas, Drain Vitality)
After the time of, not pursuit (as in ‘to go after something’).
v. to think; to know n. thought; knowledge
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.

Never occurs in dialogue or inscriptions, though the related words mindol ‘to think’, mindoraan ‘to understand’ suggest that the primary meaning is ‘to use one’s mental faculty’, not ‘believe, suppose’.
Occurs only in the compound grahmindol ‘battle-thought’ (‘strategem’).
May be closer in meaning to ‘devise’, ‘plan’, or ‘plot’ given its association with grahmindol ‘stratagem’.
Related to mindok ‘to know’, mindoraan ‘to understand’.
v. to understand, comprehend n. understanding, comprehension
Mindoraan, pah ok middovahhe lahvraan til. As you know, all his dragon-loyalists (are) mustered there. (Odahviing, 00048F05)
adj. allied, loyal adv. loyally, in the manner of an ally n. allegiance, loyalty v. to ally with, make or become loyal to
Raan mir tah! Animal allegiance pack! (Animal Allegiance Shout)
Geh, Sahloknir, kaali mir. Yes, Sahloknir, my loyal champion. (Alduin, 00035B4B)

Laknir Mal-Tu wahlaan qethsegol aarii vahrukt bonaar Vakeeza wo vaat mir wah jun do Keizaal ahrk dir ko sadon gravuun. Loknir Little-Hammer erected this stone in memory of his servant, humble Vakeeza, who swore Allegiance to the kings of Skyrim, and died in the gray autumn. (Word Wall for Mir, Animal Allegiance)
Word of Power in the Animal Allegiance Shout, unwavering loyalty, the binding of cause and strength.
Onikaan koraav gein miraad [sic]. Wisdom sees the one doorway. (Odahviing, 0004DE40)

Thoringar wahlaan qethsegol monii vahrukt, Noomi, wen dez los wah Aus nin do pogaan Ogiim ronaaz. Thoringar raised this stone for his daughter’s memory, Noomi, whose fate it was to Suffer the sting of many Orc arrows. (Word Wall for Aus, Marked for Death)
Unlike kul, specifically refers to a female child or descendant.
v. to mother, raise or create as a mother n. mother; origin; creator
Occurs only in the name Monahven ‘Throat of the World’ (lit. ‘Mother of the Wind’).
Like bormah ‘father’, original meaning may be much broader. Associated with Kyne and nature.
Throat of the World = Mother (of the) Wind (Dialogue File, 0003FA3F) (PrimaGames.com)
Do you know why I live here, at the peak of the Monahven - what you name Throat of the World? Monahven = “Mother (of the) Wind” = dragon name for Throat of the World (Paarthurnax, 0003FA3F)
Proper noun but may be used with definite articles. Refers to the entire mountain, not just the peak.

Reference to the Nordic belief that they are Children of the Sky, where the Throat of the World was “where the sky exhaled on the land and formed them” (Book, Children of the Sky). Officially noted as being dragon in origin, which either corroborates the legend or refers to ‘wind’ in a more literal sense, given the altitude and fierce winds of the mountain.
v. to focus, concentrate, give attention to; to contemplate, think n. focus, concentration, attention; contemplation, thought
Su'um ahrk morah. Breath and focus. (Paarthurnax, 000E8276)
Refers to mental focus and concentration, meditation, and long thought. Not to be used in non-mental senses such as “to focus efforts’ or ‘to concentrate forces’. See instead ro ‘balance’.
Su'um ahrk morah ‘Breath and focus’ is officially noted as “sort of a mantra for the Greybeards” (0003FAF8).
Glory (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Dialogue File, 0004591A) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Ni liivrah hin moro. Do not diminish [wither] your glory. (Paarthurnax, 0004591A)

Het nok Yngnavar Gaaf-Kodaav, wo drey Yah moro nau Frod do Krosis, nuz sinon siiv dinok ahrk dukaan. Here lies Yngnavar Ghost-Bear, who did Seek glory on the Battlefield of Sorrows, but instead found death and dishonor. (Word Wall for Yah, Aura Whisper)
Glorious (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. glorious adv. gloriously v. to glorify

Ahrk fin zul, rok drey kod, nau tol morokei frod, rul lot Taazokaan motaad voth kein! And the Voice, he did wield, on that glorious field, when great Tamriel shuddered with war! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)

Wah Krii ko morokei kein los wah zin geinmaar. Wah dir ko morokei kein los wah zin pah do Keizaal. To Kill in glorious war is to honor oneself. To die in glorious war is to honor all of Skyrim. (Word Wall for Krii, Marked for Death)
Glorious as a result of triumph, or something that will bring glory.
Name of one of the eight dragon priests.
v. to shudder, tremble, shake n. shudder, tremble, shake

Ahrk fin zul, rok drey kod, nau tol morokei frod, rul lot Taazokaan motaad voth kein! And the Voice, he did wield, on that glorious field, when great Tamriel shuddered with war! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
The shaking or trembling of the earth as from some cataclysm or great power. Does not refer to fear as in ‘to tremble with fear’.
Het nok kopraan do sonaan Romerius, wo unt Ru nol osos gogil, nuz motmah. Here lies the body of the bard Romerius, who tried to Run from some goblins, but slipped. (Word Wall for Ru, Dismay)
Primarily ‘to trip or fall’. Given motmahus ‘slippery/elusive’, may also be used to mean ‘to slip away’.
adj. slippery; elusive, tricky, difficult to grasp adv. in a slippery manner; elusively n. slipperiness; elusiveness v. to make or become slippery or elusive
Yes... one of his allies could tell us. Motmahus... But it will not be so easy to... convince one of them to betray him. Motmahus = “slippery” = “tricky” (Paarthurnax, 0004591B)
Means slippery, elusive; hard to catch, difficult to grasp.
From motmah ‘slip’ with the adjective suffix -us.
We (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 000E16F5) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Dovahkiin, fah hin kogaan mu draal! Dragonborn, for your blessing we pray! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Mu bo kotin stinselok. We fly into the sky's freedom. (Odahviing, 000E16F5)
adj. strong adv. strongly n. strength v. to strengthen
Mul qah diiv! Strength armor wyrm! (Dragon Aspect Shout)
Dovahkiin zol [sic] mul. Zu'u gahvon miri Alduin. Dovahkiin is most strong (=stronger). I yield my allegiance (to) Alduin. (Odahviing, 000E16FE)

Pah werid morokei Miraak, zok suleykaar do pah Sonaak wen Mul bolaav naal Fahluaan do Jul. All praise the glorious Miraak, most powerful of all priests, whose Strength was granted by the Gardener of Men. (Word Wall for Mul, Dragon Aspect)
Connotes power in general, physical or otherwise. Also connotes truth, rightness, the right to rule based on strength. As a Word of Power, embodies the inborn strength and power of dragonkind.
adj. strong, powerful adv. strongly, powerfully, with strength n. strength, power v. to strengthen, gain power
Suleyki mulaag, Paarthurnax. My power (has) strengthened, Paarthurnax. (Alduin, 00044968)

Het mah spaan vahdin Valkrys, wo krif voth ahkrin, nuz los folaas wah Ov mulaag do bodiis tuz. Here fell the shield maiden Valkrys, who fought bravely, but was wrong to Trust the strength of a borrowed blade. (Word Wall for Ov, Kyne’s Peace)
Refers to any form of strength or power, or the magnitude of that strength. Connotates truth, rightness, the right to rule based on strength.
adj. unmoving, unchanging, still adv. unchangingly, in a still or unmoving manner n. stillness, lack of motion or change v. to still, make or become still

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhar fin Golah wo praal het mulhaan ol gol saraan onikiv nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Bend Will)

Nii los heyv do enook mun wah lahney voth ahkrin ahrk zin leh rok feim vodahmin kotin vulom. It is duty of each man to live with courage and honor lest he fade unremembered into darkness. (Word Wall for Feim, Become Ethereal)
Means ‘person’ or ‘human’, not gender specific. Refers to an individual person.
Possibly related to mu ‘we’ or mul ‘strong’.
adj. cruel adv. cruelly v. to make or become cruel

Het nok kopraan do Iglif Iiz-Sos wo grind ok oblaan ni ko morokei vukein nuz ahst munax haalvut do liiv krasaar. Here lies the body of Iglif Ice-Blood, who met his end not in glorious combat, but at the cruel touch of the withering sickness. (World Wall for Iiz, Ice Form)

Het nok bein nahgahdinok Azaran faal munax wo unt wah gron krilot dilon do Sovngarde wah lein do jul ahrk funt. Here lies the foul necromancer Azaran the Cruel, who tried to Bind the valiant dead of Sovngarde to the world of man, and failed. (Word Wall for Gron, Become Ethereal)
Cruel in nature or disposition; unfair, unjust.
Men (plural of “man”, not “mankind”) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Dovahkiin kos fin saviik do muz! Dragonborn, be the savior of men! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Nivahriin muz fent siiv nid aaz het. Cowardly men shall find no mercy here. (Morokei, 00080103)

Het dir bruniik Rek-Grohiik Ulfeidr kriid muz ahrk sunvaar bruniik kinbok sahqon tah. Here died the savage she-wolf Ulfeidr, slayer of men and beasts, and savage leader of the Crimson Pack. (Word Wall for Tah, Animal Allegiance)
Not gender specific, means ‘humans’ rather than ‘male persons’.
Only known irregular plural noun in the language. Not to be confused with jul ‘mankind / the races of man’.
v. to eat n. eating, consumption

Vegunthar wahlaan qethsegol bormahii vahrukt, Hungunthar Tiid-Naak, kriaan se junnesejer, kroniid se Dunkreath. Vegunthar built (this) stone (in) his father’s memory, Hungunthar Time-Eater, slayer of the Kings of the East, conqueror of Dunkreath. (Word Wall for Tiid, Slow Time)
Irregular past participle naako. Featured in the dragon name Vuljotnaak ‘dark maw eat’.
adj. eaten adv. in an eaten manner, having been eaten

Qethsegol vahrukiv ahzid Viik do Briinahmaar do Sot Peyt, naako wah fin laat naal ufiik do Korvag Kol. This stone commemorates the bitter Defeat of the Sisterhood of the White Rose, eaten to the last by the Trolls of Korvag Crag. (Word Wall for Viik, Disarm)
Irregular past participle of naak ‘to eat’.
By (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 000E16FA) (POGGLE, p. 1096) (PrimaGames.com)
prep. by, according to; with; through the authority or action of
Dovahkiin, Dovahkiin, naal ok zin los vahriin, wah dein vokul mahfaeraak ahst vaal! Dragonborn, Dragonborn, by his honor is sworn, To keep evil forever at bay! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)

Naal Thu'umu, mu ofan nii nu, Dovahkiin, naal suleyk do Kaan, naal suleyk do Shor, ahrk naal suleyk do Atmorasewuth. By our Voice we give it now (to you), Dragonborn, by (the) power of Kyne, by the power of Shor, and by the power of Atmora-of-old. (Greybeards, 000C43A7)

Het mah tahrodiis tafiir Skorji Lun-Sinak, wen klov govey naal rinik hahkun rok togaat wah gahrot. Here fell the treacherous thief Skorji Leech-Fingers, whose head was removed by the very axe he was attempting to steal. (Word Wall for Lun, Marked for Death)
Zu'u uth nall [sic] thurri [sic] dein daar miiraak. I (was) ordered by my lord to keep/guard this portal. (Nahkriin, 000E16FA)

Wulfik wahlaan qethsegol judii vahrukt, Hrefna Ruvaak-Om, wen miin Diin sos do naan jul. Wulfik raised this stone in memory of his queen, Hrefna Raven-Hair, whose eyes could Freeze the blood of any man. (Word Wall for Diin, Frost Breath)
Zu'u Alduin, zok sahrot do naan ko Lein. I (am still) Alduin, most mighty of any in Mundus (the world). (Alduin, 000ED362)
Typically in reference to a person, not inanimate things.
Used as both a pronoun ‘any/anyone’, and an adjective as in ‘any thing’.
May only occur as the root of lumnaar ‘valley’.
Wuld nah kest! Whirlwind fury tempest! (Whirlwind Sprint Shout)
Oblivion loost nid Nah med spaan vahdin beyn. Oblivion hath no Fury like a shield maiden scorned. (Word Wall for Nah, Whirlwind Sprint)
Word of Power that embodies the sudden release of strength, speed, or power. Used as a curse to express anger.

Het nok bein nahgahdinok Azaran faal Munax, wo unt wah Gron krilot dilon do Sovngarde wah lein do jul, ahrk funt. Here lies the foul necromancer Azaran the Cruel, who tried to Bind the valiant dead of Sovngarde to the world of man, and failed. (Word Wall for Gron, Become Ethereal)
From dinok, ‘death’, possibly a compound with nah ‘fury’ and/or portmanteau with gahvon ‘to yield’ meaning ‘fury yields death’.
v. to feed; to be fed by n. feeding
Bahloki nahkip sillesejoor. My hunger has been fed by mortal souls. (Alduin, 000CDDF1)
Zu'u lost kriaan hi ont, nu hin sille fen nahkip suleyki. I've killed you once, now your souls will feed my power. (Alduin, 000ED365)
There are many hungers it is better to deny than to feed. Dreh ni nahkip. Dreh ni nahkip = “do not feed” (Paarthurnax, 0003F9E2, 0003F9E2)
Can refer to the feeding of any power or force, esp. from the devouring of souls.
Possibly a compound of naak ‘to eat’ and kip ‘food’.
v. to kill in revenge; to exact vengeance n. revenge, vengeance

Ahrk ond drey sahrot Heimverlund meyz, nol hevno Brom, med Strun do uznahgaar nahkriin nol Sovngarde nimaar. And lo did the mighty Heimverlund come, from the brutal North, like a Storm of unbridled vengeance from Sovngarde itself. (Word Wall for Strun, Storm Call)
Compound of nah ‘fury’ and kriin ‘to slay’, ‘to slay in fury’.
Namesake of one of the dragon priest masks.
adj. living, alive adv. in a living manner v. to liven, enliven, make or become living
Word of Power, appears only in the Shout used by Tsun to return a person from Sovngarde to Nirn. Generally not used in regular speech. See instead nahlaas ‘alive’.
From nahlaas ‘alive’, and laas ‘life’, likely truncated from nahlaas to form a Word of Power.
adj. alive adv. while alive v. to liven, enliven, make or become alive
Pogaan nahlaas, vokrii wah jun. Many alive, restored to (the) light. (Paarthurnax, 000D2CF5)

Sigruuf wahlaan qethsegol briinahii vahrukt, Lanal, wen brit luft los ol kinzon ahrk sot ol Nus, dwiirok nol nahlaas ozinvey. Sigruuf raised this stone for his sister, Lanal, whose beautiful face was as sharp and white as a Statue, carved from living ivory. (Word Wall for Nus, Ice Form)

Qethsegol vahrukiv kiir jun Jafnhar, wo los ag nahlaas naal Yol do lot dovah Lodunost. This stone commemorates the child king Jafnhar, who was burned alive by the Fire of the great dragon Lodunost. (Word Wall for Yol, Fire Breath)
Can describe a living person, or something metaphorically said to be living or alive.
Silenced (verb) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 0009E072) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. silent adv. silently n. silence v. to silence
Nuz aan sul, fent alok, fod fin vul dovah nok, fen kos nahlot mahfaeraak ahrk ruz! But a day, shall arise, when the dark dragon's lies, will be silenced forever and then! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Thu'umii los nahlot. His Voice is silenced. (Dragon, 0009E072)
In reference to the Voice, refers to death or the removal of former power.
On (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Dialogue File, 0004DE42) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
prep. on, upon; at, down upon

Ahrk fin zul, rok drey kod, nau tol morokei frod, rul lot Taazokaan motaad voth kein! And the Voice, he did wield, on that glorious field, when great Tamriel shuddered with war! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
The freedom of the sky beckons! Yet I stay here, nau gol, as promised. Nau gol = “on earth” = “grounded” (Odahviing, 0004DE42)
Kendov krif ok kosiil Vokul, nuz jun Gaar niin nau ok hokoron. The warrior fights his inner evils, but the king unleashes them on his enemies. (Word Wall for Gaar, Cyclone)

Means ‘on top of’ or ‘down upon’. Does not mean ‘active’ as in ‘to turn on’. Not used in reference to time as in ‘on time’ or ‘on this day’. Not used to indicate condition, as in ‘on cue’ or ‘on demand’.
Occurs only in the dragon name Paarthurnax ‘ambition overlord cruelty’ and as the root of munax ‘cruel’.
Given relations to munax, is closer in meaning to ‘injustice’ than ‘atrocity’, the cruelties of unfair circumstances or something that is unyielding and beyond control.
Occurs only in the dragon name Durnehviir ‘curse never dying’.
Negative related to ni ‘not’ and nid ‘no’.
Wo lost fron wah ney dov, ahrk fin reyliik do jul, voth aan suleyk wah ronit faal krein! Who was kin to both wyrm, and the races of man, with a power to rival the sun! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)

Nonvul Bron, mahfaeraak dahmaan sahrot Vahlok wen lot ahkrin shaan ney muz ahrk dovah. Noble Nord, forever remember the mighty Guardian whose great courage inspired both men and dragons. (Word Wall for Shaan, Battle Fury)
Not used as an adjective meaning ‘two’ as in ‘both kings’.
Not (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Dialogue File, 000D2DBB) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Ni faas, Dovahkiin! (I do) not fear (you), Dragonborn! (Odahviing, 000D2DBB)
And he is no fool. Ni mey, rinik gut nol. Ni mey = “no fool”, Rinik gut nol = “very far from” (Paarthurnax, 000556DB)
Ni liivrah hin moro. Do not diminish [wither] your glory. (Paarthurnax, 0004591A)

Het nok kopraan do Iglif Iiz-Sos, wo grind ok oblaan ni ko morokei vukein, nuz ahst munax haalvut do liiv krasaar. Here lies the body of Iglif Ice-Blood, who met his end not in glorious combat, but at the cruel touch of the withering sickness. (Word Wall for Iiz, Ice Form)
Broadly used to indicate a negative of any kind. Should be used instead of nid ‘no’ to indicate a negative in phrases such as zu’u ni mey ‘I am no fool’ unless for emphasis.
adv. no adj. no, none n. nothing pron. none
Ful, losei Dovahkiin? Zu'u koraav nid nol dov do hi. So, you're the Dragonborn? I see nothing of the dragon about you. (Alduin, 000C8EA0)
Lingrah krosis saraan Strundu'ul, voth nid balaan klov praan nau. Long sorrowfully (has) waited the Stormcrown, with no worthy head to rest on. (Greybeards, 000C43AB)
Oblivion loost nid Nah med spaan vahdin beyn. Oblivion hath no Fury like a shield maiden scorned. (Word Wall for Nah, Whirlwind Sprint)
Interchangeable with ni ‘not’ in some cases, such as zu’u nid mey ‘I am no fool’. Ni is more common but nid may be used as a matter of emphasis or formality.
pron. it; an inanimate object; a concept or abstract idea

Naal Thu'umu, mu ofan nii nu, Dovahkiin, naal suleyk do Kaan, naal suleyk do Shor, ahrk naal suleyk do Atmorasewuth. By our Voice we give it now (to you), Dragonborn, by (the) power of Kyne, by the power of Shor, and by the power of Atmora-of-old. (Greybeards, 000C43A6)
Ful nii los. Ful nii los. = “so it is” = “so be it” (Paarthurnax, 0009C20C)

Nii los heyv do enook mun wah lahney voth ahkrin ahrk zin, leh rok Feim vodahmin kotin vulom. It is the duty of each man to live with courage and honor, lest he Fade unremembered into darkness. (Word Wall for Feim, Become Ethereal)
Third person singular neuter. May refer to inanimate objects (a crown), or abstractions as the subject of ‘to be’ as in ‘it is an honor’ or ‘it is cold here’.
Homophone with ni ‘not’. May lengthen pronunciation or stress to avoid confusion.
Niid koraav zeim dinoksetiid. (There is) no seeing through (the) end of time. (Paarthurnax, 0009C20D)
Kendov krif ok kosil Vokul, nuz jun Gaar niin nau ok hokoron. The warrior fights his inner evils, but the king unleashes them on his enemies. (Word Wall for Gaar, Cyclone)
Homophone with nin ‘to sting’. Only known pronoun with an explicit accusative form.
adj. cowardly adv. cowardly, like a coward n. coward v. to cower, lose courage, become cowardly; to dishearten, dismay, make cowardly
Faal Kel...?! Nikriinne… Elder Scroll...? Cowards... (Alduin, 000CD9DE)
Connotes a loss of courage, unwillingness to face a fear, danger, or challenge.
Likely a compound of ni ‘not’ and krin ‘courageous’.
adj. void, empty adv. emptily, in a void manner n. void, emptiness v. to empty, make void
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
Unknown whether a general word or a proper noun referring to the space beyond the Aurbis.

Ahrk ond drey sahrot Heimverlund meyz, nol hevno Brom, med Strun do uznahgaar nahkriin nol Sovngarde nimaar. And lo did the mighty Heimverlund come, from the brutal North, like a Storm of unbridled vengeance from Sovngarde itself. (Word Wall for Strun, Storm Call)
Third person singular neuter reflexive. Used for emphasis (e.g. ‘the Empire itself’).
From nii ‘it’ with the reflexive suffix -maar.
v. to sting, strike; to pierce n. sting, strike; piercing
Come, Dovahkiin. Nin Yol. Strike me with the fire of your Thu'um. (Paarthurnax, 000559DC)

Thoringar wahlaan qethsegol monii vahrukt, Noomi, wen dez los wah Aus nin do pogaan Ogiim ronaaz. Thoringar raised this stone for his daughter’s memory, Noomi, whose fate it was to Suffer the sting of many Orc arrows. (Word Wall for Aus, Marked for Death)
Connotes a painful or piercing strike, as from an arrow, or the burning of flames.

Het mah faasnu ronaan Undveld, aar, kriid grohiik, ahrk drog do Lot Nir. Here fell the fearless archer Undveld, servant, slayer of wolves, and lord of the Great Hunt. (Word Wall for Nir, Aura Whisper)
Word of Power, encompasses the bond between hunter and prey, and a hunter’s skill and sight.
May share root with nos ‘to strike’ and nin ‘to sting’.
Featured in the dragon name Sahloknir ‘phantom sky hunt’.
Zu'u unslaad! Zu'u nis oblaan! I am eternal! I cannot end! (be ended/be killed) (Alduin, 000ED359)

Het nok brit kaaz Anurassa, wen faad nis kos evenaar orin naal Krah dinok. Here lies the beautiful cat Anurassa, whose warmth cannot be extinguished even by the Cold of death. (Word Wall for Krah, Frost Breath)
From ni ‘not’, possibly a contraction of ni and an unattested word his ‘can’ analogous to losei (los hi).
adj. cowardly; disloyal; having abandoned an oath adv. cowardly, like a coward n. cowardice; disloyalty v. to become cowardly; to abandon an oath
Ruth wah nivahriin joor! Rage/curses to (you) cowardly mortal! (Alduin, 000C64F1)
Draal ni fah Drem, fah grik los hind do sahlo ahrk nivahriin. Pray not for Peace, for such is the wish of the weak and cowardly. (Word Wall for Drem, Kyne’s Peace)
Usage is comparable to nikriin ‘cowardly’, but etymology suggests the abandonment of loyalty. May have originally meant this but grew to encompass a broader meaning.
Likely a compound of ni ‘not’ and vahriin ‘sworn’.
Lie(s) (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
v. to lie (buried), rest (as in death); to lay or be laid to rest; to lie, tell a falsehood n. rest; lie
Nuz aan sul, fent alok, fod fin vul dovah nok, fen kos nahlot mahfaeraak ahrk ruz! But a day, shall arise, when the dark dragon's lies, will be silenced forever and then! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)

Het nok Yngnavar Gaaf-Kodaav, wo drey Yah moro nau Frod do Krosis, nuz sinon siiv dinok ahrk dukaan. Here lies Yngnavar Ghost-Bear, who did Seek glory on the Battlefield of Sorrows, but instead found death and dishonor. (Word Wall for Yah, Aura Whisper)
Specifically refers to death, the final resting place of a body or thing, usually buried.

Used in the Song of the Dragonborn to mean ‘lie’ as in ‘deceive’, but used extensively in Word Walls as ‘to lie buried’. Should only be used pertaining to death, and lo ‘to deceive’ should be used instead pertaining to deception.
From (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 000556DB) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
prep. from, indicating difference or separation; indicating source or origin
Paaz Keizaal fen kos stin nol bein Alduin jot! Fair Skyrim will be free from foul Alduin's maw! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Ni mey, rinik gut nol. No fool, very far from. (Paarthurnax, 000556DB)
Het nok kopraan do sonaan Romerius, wo unt Ru nol osos gogil, nuz motmah. Here lies the body of the bard Romerius, who tried to Run from some goblins, but slipped. (Word Wall for Ru, Dismay)

Sigruuf wahlaan qethsegol briinahii vahrukt, Lanal, wen brit luft los ol kinzon ahrk sot ol Nus, dwiirok nol nahlaas ozinvey. Sigruuf raised this stone for his sister, Lanal, whose beautiful face was as sharp and white as a Statue, carved from living ivory. (Word Wall for Nus, Ice Form)

Ahrk ond drey sahrot Heimverlund meyz, nol hevno Brom, med Strun do uznahgaar nahkriin nol Sovngarde nimaar. And lo did the mighty Heimverlund come, from the brutal North, like a Storm of unbridled vengeance from Sovngarde itself. (Word Wall for Strun, Storm Call)
Do ‘of’ and se ‘of’ are more commonly used to indicate origin than nol.
adj. noble, honorable adv. nobly, honorably n. nobleness, nobility v. to distinguish, ennoble, dignify, make or become noble

Nonvul Bron, mahfaeraak dahmaan sahrot Vahlok wen lot ahkrin shaan ney muz ahrk dovah. Noble Nord, forever remember the mighty Guardian whose great courage inspired both men and dragons. (Word Wall for Shaan, Battle Fury)

Qethsegol vahrukiv vur do Faal Vahlok, nonvul aar se dovah wen dez lost wah qahnaar tahrodiis Miraak. This stone commemorates the valor of the Guardian, noble servant of dragons whose fate it was to vanquish the treacherous Miraak. (Word Wall for Vur, Valor)
Means ‘honorable’ and ‘worthy’ rather than ‘highborn’, not pertaining to royalty or royal families.
Fierce (“Fiercest” in the Song of the Dragonborn) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. fierce adv. fiercely n. fierceness, ferocity v. to make or become fierce
Ahrk fin norok paal graan fod nust hon zindro zaan! And the fiercest foes rout when they hear triumph's shout! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Fierce or unyielding in battle, fighting to the last; does not connotate viciousness or wildness, as in a fierce animal. See instead fel ‘feral’ or bruniik ‘savage’.
The superlative meaning in the Song of the Dragonborn is implied and should be considered inherent to norok.
v. to strike, attack n. strike, attack

Qethsegol vahrukiv Hrodmir fin Krent, wo sov pah ok eruvos ahrk faraan wah Nos tum krivaan do ok zeymah. This stone commemorates Hrodmir the Broken, who spent all his years and fortune to Strike down the killer of his brother. (Word Wall for Nos, Cyclone)
Word of Power, to strike with a weapon, Voice, or withheld power. Not used to mean ‘inflict’ as in ‘to strike fear’.
Now (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 0004DE35) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adv. now; currently, presently; yet, still
Huzrah nu, kul do od, wah aan bok lingrah vod, Ahrk fin tey, boziik fun, do fin gein! Hearken now, sons of snow, to an age, long ago, and the tale, boldly told, of the one! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Hin aar, orin nu. Your servant/slave, even now. (Odahviing, 0004DE35)

Het mah sahrot konahrik Aaban, kiin se Klo se Alikr, praan nu denek Keizaal. Here fell the mighty warlord Aaban, born of the Sand of the Alik’r, at rest now in the soil of Skyrim. (Word Wall for Klo, Slow Time)
Not to be confused with the suffix -nu seen in the words hahnu ‘dream’ and faasnu ‘fearless’.

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhor fin Golah, wo praal het mulhaan ol Gol saraan onikiv, nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Bend Will)
May relate to sinon ‘instead’, indicating the contrary, root nuz ‘but’.
Conjunction only, used to indicate the contrary, not used as in ‘only a dragon can fly’ or ‘an only child’.
Iiz slen nus! Ice flesh statue! (Ice Form Shout)

Sigruuf wahlaan qethsegol briinahii vahrukt, Lanal, wen brit luft los ol kinzon ahrk sot ol Nus, dwiirok nol nahlaas ozinvey. Sigruuf raised this stone for his sister, Lanal, whose beautiful face was as sharp and white as a Statue, carved from living ivory. (Word Wall for Nus, Ice Form)
Word of Power, permanent and unchanging, facilitates and the transition between flesh and ice.
They/Those (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 000ED363) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Ahrk fin norok paal graan fod nust hon zindro zaan! And the fiercest foes rout when they hear triumph's shout! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Nust wo ni qiilaan fen kos duaan. Those who (do) not bow will be devoured. (Alduin, 000ED363)
Pronoun only. Not to be confused with the adjective daar ‘this/these/those’.
But (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 0003FA46) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Nuz aan sul, fent alok, fod fin vul dovah nok, fen kos nahlot mahfaeraak ahrk ruz! But a day, shall arise, when the dark dragon's lies, will be silenced forever and then! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Viik nuz ni kron. Defeat but not victory. (Paarthurnax, 0003FA46)

Het nok Yngnavar Gaaf-Kodaav, wo drey Yah moro nau Frod do Krosis, nuz sinon siiv dinok ahrk dukaan. Here lies Yngnavar Ghost-Bear, who did Seek glory on the Battlefield of Sorrows, but instead found death and dishonor. (Word Wall for Yah, Aura Whisper)
Used as a conjunction only to indicate the contrary; not used as in ‘there is but one king’ or ‘no one knew but me’.
End (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Dialogue File, 000ED359) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
v. to end; to die, be killed n. end; death
Zu'u unslaad! Zu'u nis oblaan! I am eternal! I cannot end! (be ended/be killed) (Alduin, 000ED359)

Het nok kopraan do Iglif Iiz-Sos, wo grind ok oblaan ni ko morokei vukein, nuz ahst munax haalvut do liiv krasaar. Here lies the body of Iglif Ice-Blood, who met his end not in glorious combat, but at the cruel touch of the withering sickness. (Word Wall for Iiz, Ice Form)
Typically refers to death (of a person, period of time, rule, etc.).
Typically refers to death (of a person, period of time, rule, etc.).
Oblivion loost nid Nah med spaan vahdin beyn. Oblivion hath no Fury like a shield maiden scorned. (Word Wall for Nah, Whirlwind Sprint)
Origin of the Tamrielic name ‘Oblivion’ is unknown. Appearance as a loanword in the Word Walls indicates it was contemporary with the ancient Nords.
Snow (Call Dragon Shout) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Huzrah nu, kul do od, wah aan bok lingrah vod, ahrk fin tey, boziik fun, do fin gein! Hearken now, sons of snow, to an age, long ago, and the tale, boldly told, of the one! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Word of Power, relates to both the sky and the land of Skyrim.
Featured prominently in the dragon name Odahviing ‘snow hunter wing’.
adj. snowy adv. snowily n. snowiness v. to make or become snowy

Qethsegol vahrukiv key Sarvirra, zok krin Raan alun wah fonaar odus frod, ahrk ofan ok sil fah ok drog. This stone commemorates the horse Sarvirra, the most courageous Animal ever to charge the snowy battlefields, and give his soul for his lord. (Word Wall for Raan, Animal Allegiance)
v. to receive, earn, acquire n. reception, acquisition, the act of earning

Het mah Arnvid faal Staadnau, wen Haas denos mindin Kein do Galik, kolos rok ofaal dilos ahraan. Here fell Arnvid the Unbound, whose Health declined after the War of Pines, in which he received a deadly wound. (Word Wall for Haas, Drain Vitality)
v. to give n. giving; gift
Zu'u lost ofan hin laan. I have given your want/request. (Odahviing, 00048F05)

Naal Thu'umu, mu ofan nii nu, Dovahkiin, naal suleyk do Kaan, naal suleyk do Shor, ahrk naal suleyk do Atmorasewuth. By our Voice we give it now (to you), Dragonborn, by (the) power of Kyne, by the power of Shor, and by the power of Atmora-of-old. (Greybeards, 000C43A7)

Qethsegol vahrukiv key Sarvirra, zok krin Raan alun wah fonaar odus frod, ahrk ofan ok sil fah ok drog. This stone commemorates the horse Sarvirra, the most courageous Animal ever to charge the snowy battlefields, and give his soul for his lord. (Word Wall for Raan, Animal Allegiance)

Thoringar wahlaan qethsegol monii vahrukt, Noomi, wen dez los wah Aus nin do pogaan Ogiim ronaaz. Thoringar raised this stone for his daughter’s memory, Noomi, whose fate it was to Suffer the sting of many Orc arrows. (Word Wallf for Aus, Marked for Death)
His (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 0009E058) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
Dovahkiin, Dovahkiin, naal ok zin los vahriin, wah dein vokul mahfaeraak ahst vaal! Dragonborn, Dragonborn, by his honor is sworn, To keep evil forever at bay! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Dovahkiin los ok dovahkriid. The Dragonborn is his dragonslayer - The Dragonborn slew him. (Dragon, 0009E058)

Qethsegol vahrukiv key Sarvirra, zok krin Raan alun wah fonaar odus frod, ahrk ofan ok sil fah ok drog. This stone commemorates the horse Sarvirra, the most courageous Animal ever to charge the snowy battlefields, and give his soul for his lord. (Word Wall for Raan, Animal Allegiance)
The possessive suffix -ii can be used instead of ok to indicate third person possession.

Qethsegol vahrukiv kril Thjodrek, wo dir zohungaar ko Grah do Vith Okaaz. This stone commemorates the brave Thjodrek, who died heroically in the Battle of the Serpent Sea. (Word Wall for Grah, Elemental Fury)

Bekkhild wahlaan qethsegol ahmulii vahrukt, Eyolf, wen veysun los sizaan ko vul Kest ko Okaaz do Luv. Bekkhild raised this stone for her husband, Eyolf, whose ship was lost in a dark Tempest in the Sea of Tears. (Word Wall for Kest, Whirlwind Sprint)
Only known occurrences are in place names.
As (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 000EDF49) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adv. as, similarly, equally conj. in the degree or manner of; while, when
Sahrot Thu'um, med aan tuz, vey zeim hokoron pah, ol fin Dovahkiin komeyt ok rein! Mighty Thu'um, like a blade, cut through enemies all, as the Dragonborn issued his roar! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Pruzah ol aar. Good as (a) slave. (Alduin, 000EDF49)

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhor fin Golah, wo praal het mulhaan ol Gol saraan onikiv, nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Dragon Aspect)

Het nok Fjolmod Bein-Su, wo pook ol pogaas nau gol ol ok kopraan dreh nu ko golt. Here lies Fjolmod Foul-Air, who stank as much on earth as his body does now in the ground. (Word Wall for Su, Elemental Fury)
Used to mean ‘while/when’ only in the Song of the Dragonborn. Should only be used to form comparisons.

Wulfik wahlaan qethsegol judii vahrukt, Hrefna Ruvaak-Om, wen miin Diin sos do naan jul. Wulfik raised this stone in memory of his queen, Hrefna Raven-Hair, whose eyes could Freeze the blood of any man. (Word Wall for Diin, Frost Breath)
Used to refer to human hair rather than animal hair or fur.

Ahrk ond drey sahrot Heimverlund meyz, nol hevno Brom, med Strun do uznahgaar nahkriin nol Sovngarde nimaar. And lo did the mighty Heimverlund come, from the brutal North, like a Storm of unbridled vengeance from Sovngarde itself. (Word Wall for Strun, Storm Call)
Rarely used, calls attention to a particular statement or detail.
adj. wise adv. wisely v. to wisen
They see me as master. Wuth. Onik. Old and wise. (Paarthurnax, 0003F88E)

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhor fin Golah, wo praal het mulhaan ol Gol saraan onikiv, nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Bend Will)
I can be trusted. I know this. But they do not. Onikaan ni ov dovah. It is always wise to mistrust a dovah. Onikaan ni ov dovah = “Wisdom is not trusting a dragon” (Paarthurnax, 0003C574)

Qethsegol vahrukiv lot Miraak – sonaak do lot onikaan, aar do faal Diiv, ahrk hokoron do jul. This stone commemorates the great Miraak – priest of great wisdom, servant of the Wyrm, and enemy of man. (Word Wall for Diiv, Dragon Aspect)

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhor fin Golah, wo praal het mulhaan ol Gol saraan onikiv, nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Bend Will)
To gain wisdom, become wise, have an experience that gives wisdom.
adv. once, formerly, at one time; already
Zeymahi lost ont du'ul Bormahu. My brother was once the crown of our father. (Paarthurnax, 0009C213)
Zu'u lost kriaan hi ont, nu hin sille fen nahkip suleyki. I've killed you once, now your souls will feed my power. (Alduin, 000ED365)

Het ont kriist Miraak, wo ahtiid ok sahvot ol Qah, spaan naal Deyra fah ok unslaad midun. Here once stood Miraak, who wore his faith as Armor, shielded by the Daedra for his unending loyalty. (Word Wall for Qah, Dragon Aspect)
Likely from English ‘once’. Used to mean ‘in the past’, not ‘one time’ (‘he struck once’) or ‘whenever’ (‘once he strikes, strike back’).
adv. even, fully, quite (used to emphasize coincidence, occurrence, or unlikeliness)
Orin brit ro. “(A) fully beautiful balance” = dragon phrase for irony. (Odahviing, 0004DE36)
Hin aar, orin nu. Your servant/slave, even now. (Odahviing, 0004DE35)

Het nok brit kaaz Anurassa, wen faad nis kos evenaar orin naal Krah dinok. Here lies the beautiful cat Anurassa, whose warmth cannot be extinguished even by the Cold of death. (Word Wall for Krah, Frost Breath)
Can indicates unlikeliness. Emphasizes an adjective or agent.
Adverb only. Not used to mean ‘even’ as in ‘equal’.
adj. uncertain or unspecified; an unspecified number of

Nau daar revak golt drey Freda zahrahmiik ek Laas, ful tol ek pogaan kiir filok, ahrk osos sul qahnaar ek hokoron. On this sacred ground did Freda sacrifice her Life, so that her many children might escape, and some day vanquish her enemies. (Word Wall for Laas, Aura Whisper)
Het nok kopraan do sonaan Romerius, wo unt Ru nol osos gogil, nuz motmah. Here lies the body of the bard Romerius, who tried to Run from some goblins, but slipped. (Word Wall for Ru, Dismay)
Not technically a pronoun but may be used similarly (osos fen hon ‘some (one) will listen’).
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
v. to trust, have confidence in, rely on n. trust, confidence, reliance
Kaan drem ov! Kyne peace trust! (Kyne’s Peace Shout)
I can be trusted. I know this. But they do not. Onikaan ni ov dovah. It is always wise to mistrust a dovah. Onikaan ni ov dovah = “Wisdom is not trusting a dragon” (Paarthurnax, 0003C574 )

Het mah spaan vahdin Valkrys, wo krif voth ahkrin, nuz los folaas wah Ov mulaag do bodiis tuz. Here fell the shield maiden Valkrys, who fought bravely, but was wrong to Trust the strength of a borrowed blade. (Word Wall for Ov, Kyne’s Peace)

Word of Power, implies lowering one’s guard or suspicion (around a predator or fellow dragon), inhibiting territorial urges. To believe in or depend on the strength of something (a weapon, force, or power).
adj. ivory, ivory-like, made of ivory adv. in an ivory-like manner, as if made of ivory n. ivory; the quality of being like ivory v. to make ivory; to become like ivory

Sigruuf wahlaan qethsegol briinahii vahrukt, Lanal, wen brit luft los ol kinzon ahrk sot ol Nus, dwiirok nol nahlaas ozinvey. Sigruuf raised this stone for his sister, Lanal, whose beautiful face was as sharp and white as a Statue, carved from living ivory. (Word Wall for Nus, Ice Form)

Precious to the ancient Nords, whose main source of ivory would have been mammoths, horkers, and sabre cats. As an adjective, connotes something perfect, valuable, and perhaps deadly given the dangerous means to obtain it.
adj. shamed, ashamed adv. ashamedly n. shame, ashamedness v. to shame
I do not know how he came to be caught. But the bronjun... the Jarl... was very proud of his pet. Paak! Paak = “shame” - said with deep disgust. (Paarthurnax, 00045D09)
Often used as an interjection to indicate despicable or horrid circumstances, or as a taunt, impending shame (in defeat).

Ahrk fin norok paal graan fod nust hon zindro zaan, Dovahkiin, fah hin kogaan mu draal! And the fiercest foes rout when they hear triumph's shout, Dragonborn, for your blessing we pray! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
More conversational than hokoron ‘enemy’, which is more common in formal speech or writing.
v. to ambition, seek after or aspire to, crave, yearn; to pursue n. ambition, desire
Occurs only in the dragon name Paarthurnax ‘ambition cruelty overlord’.

Close synonym to bahlok ‘hunger’, the drive to achieve or accomplish, typically through strength or power. Not positive or constructive in connotation as the English word ‘aspiration’, connotes acts of dominance.
Fair (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 00055771) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. fair adv. fairly n. fairness v. to make or become fair
Paaz Keizaal fen kos stin nol bein Alduin jot! Fair Skyrim will be free from foul Alduin's maw! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)

Qethsegol vahrukiv paaz kulaas Yrsa, wo ensosin pah do Taazokaan voth ek Dun ahrk brii. This stone commemorates the fair princess Yrsa, who bewitched all of Tamriel with her Grace and beauty. (Word Wall for Dun, Elemental Fury)
Closer in meaning to ‘great’, ‘beautiful’, or ‘pleasant’ (‘a fair day’), should typically not be used to mean ‘equal’ or ‘just’.
All (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 000CD9DF) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. all, the whole of; every adv. all, wholly, entirely, completely pron. all, everyone
Sahrot Thu'um, med aan tuz, vey zeim hokoron pah, ol fin Dovahkiin komeyt ok rein! Mighty Thu'um, like a blade, cut through enemies all, as the Dragonborn issued his roar! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Meyye! Tahrodiis aanne! Him hinde pah liiv! Zu'u hin daan! Fools! Treacherous slaves! Your hopes (are) all withered! I (am) your doom. (Alduin, 000CD9DF)

Pah werid morokei Miraak, zok suleykaar do pah Sonaak wen Mul bolaav naal Fahluaan do Jul. All praise the glorious Miraak, most powerful of all priests, whose Strength was granted by the Gardener of Men. (Word Wall for Mul, Dragon Aspect)
adj. arrogant adv. arrogantly n. arrogance v. to make or become arrogant
Alduin always was pahlok - arrogant in his power. Uznahgar paar. He took domination as his birthright. Uznahgar [paar] = unending ambition. (Paarthurnax, 0004591A)
You did what was necessary. Alduin had flown far from the path of right action in his pahlok. (Paarthurnax, 0009C219)
For dragons, the belief of power or rule that one is not right to, heedless of consequence or greater strength.
May share root with paar ‘ambition’ or relate to bahlok ‘hunger’.
v. to write n. writing; writ
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
Possibly from kel ‘scroll’, though kel is generally attested to refer to an Elder Scroll, which is not ‘written’ by conventional means.

Qethsegol vahrukiv ahzid Viik do Briinahmaar do Sot Peyt, naako wah fin laat naal ufiik do Korvag Kol. This stone commemorates the bitter Defeat of the Sisterhood of the White Rose, eaten to the last by the Trolls of Korvag Crag. (Word Wall for Viik, Disarm)
The flower, see alok for the verb ‘to rise’.

Qethsegol vahrukiv Kendov se Ved Ronax, Sille nu yoriik pindaar se Sovngarde pah Ul. This stone commemorates the warriors of the Black Regiment, whose souls now march on the plains of Sovngarde for all Eternity. (Word Wall for Ul, Slow Time)

Het mah Hrothmar, Bah Grohiik do bruniik pindaar. Aal ok sil rovaan Sovngarde mahfaeraak. Here fell Hrothmar, Wrath Wolf of the savage plains. May his soul wander Sovngarde forever. (Word Wall for Bah, Storm Call)
Refers to a geographical plain, more general than frod ‘battlefield’ which specifically refers to a field of battle.
v. to have, possess n. possession

Het nok kopraan do Svolo, wo piraak mulaag wah kriin dovah nuz ni gaan wah kriin pogaan. Here lies the body of Svolo, who possessed the strength to slay dragons, but not the stamina to slay many. (Word Wall for Gaan, Drain Vitality)
To possess a trait, skill, power, or ability. Does not refer to supernatural possession. Unknown if it can refer to the ownership of property.
adj. many, numerous pron. many (of something)
Pogaan nahlaas, vokrii wah jun [sic]. Many alive, restored to (the) light. (Paarthurnax, 000D2CF5)

Het nok kopraan do Svolo, wo piraak mulaag wah kriin dovah nuz ni gaan wah kriin pogaan. Here lies the body of Svolo, who possessed the strength to slay dragons, but not the stamina to slay many. (Word Wall for Gaan, Drain Vitality)

Nau daar revak golt drey Freda zahrahmiik ek Laas, ful tol ek pogaan kiir filok, ahrk osos sul qahnaar ek hokoron. On this sacred ground did Freda sacrifice her Life, so that her many children might escape, and some day vanquish her enemies. (Word Wall for Laas, Aura Whisper)
Used with countable nouns (people, animals, things). See pogaas ‘much’ for the equivalent used with uncountable nouns.
adj. much; great in measure or degree

Het nok Faal Vahlok, wo kron pogaas moro. Fah ok unslaad mid, rok aav dilon voth lot zin. Here lies the Guardian, who won much glory. For his eternal loyalty, he joins the dead with great honor. (Word Wall for Mid, Battle Fury)

Het nok Fjolmod Bein-Su, wo pook ol pogaas nau gol ol ok kopraan dreh nu ko golt. Here lies Fjolmod Foul-Air, who stank as much on earth as his body does now in the ground. (Word Wall for Su, Elemental Fury)
Used with uncountable nouns (abstract). See pogaan ‘many’ for the equivalent used with countable nouns. Also used in comparisons, but not ‘so much’ or ‘too much’. Not a noun as in ‘much of the time’.
v. to stink, reek n. stink, stench

Het nok Fjolmod Bein-Su, wo pook ol pogaas nau gol ol ok kopraan dreh nu ko golt. Here lies Fjolmod Foul-Air, who stank as much on earth as his body does now in the ground. (Word Wall for Su, Elemental Fury)
The stink of decay, rot, and death.
v. to sit, lie n. seat; sitting

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhor fin Golah, wo praal het mulhaan ol Gol saraan onikiv, nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Bend Will)
To sit, or for dragons, to lie down or otherwise rest on the ground or a perch in an upright position. Compare to nok ‘to lie’ and praan ‘to rest’, which both refer to death and burial.
v. to rest (upon); to lie in rest; to lay to rest, bury n. rest; death, the state of death
Lingrah krosis saraan Strundu'ul, voth nid balaan klov praan nau. Long sorrowfully (has) waited the Stormcrown, with no worthy head to rest on. (Greybeards, 000C43AB)

Het nok kopraan do Hela, Fahdon wah pah sivaas aar do Kaan. Aal rek siiv unahzaal praan ko Feykro do Hahnu. Here lies the body of Hela, friend to all beasts and servant of Kyne. May she find eternal rest in the Forest of Dreams. (Word Wall for Kaan, Kyne’s Peace)

Het mah sahrot konahrik Aaban, kiin se Klo se Alikr, praan nu denek Keizaal. Here fell the mighty warlord Aaban, born of the Sand of the Alik’r, at rest now in the soil of Skyrim. (Word Wall for Klo, Slow Time)
To rest motionless in or upon something. Commonly used in reference to death along with nok ‘to lie’. See praal ‘to sit’ for a word that does not connotate death.
v. to foretell, prophesy; to predict, warn of n. foretelling, prophecy, premonition; prediction, portent, warning

Ahrk fin Kel lost prodah, do ved viing ko fin krah, tol fod zeymah win kein meyz fundein! And the Scrolls have foretold, of black wings in the cold, that when brothers wage war come unfurled! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Ah. I have expected you. Prodah. (Paarthurnax, 0003FA40)
To foretell or predict, as due to prophecy, or the culmination of circumstances or consequences.
Likely inspired by words derived from the prefixes pro- and pre- meaning ‘before’, such as ‘prophet’, ‘prophecy’, and ‘premonition’.
adj. best adv. best, in the best way n. the quality of being best; something that is best v. to best, become better than, get the better of; to make or become best
Pruzaan Zun ko Keizaal los hahdrim do dwiin-sil kendov. The best Weapon in Skyrim is the mind of a steel-souled warrior. (Word Wall for Zun, Disarm)
Orin pruzaan dwiin aal kreh ahrk kren, nuz Slen do vahzah muz los sindugahvon. Even the best steel may bend and break, but the Flesh of a true man is unyielding. (Word Wall for Slen, Ice Form)
adj. good, well (in state, quality, or condition); fitting adv. good, well; fittingly n. goodness, wellness v. to make or become good or well
Pruzah wundunne wah Wuth Gein. Good travels to the old one. (Odahviing, 0009E069)
Krif krin. Pruzah! (You) fight couragously [sic]. Good! (Mirmulnir, 0005637F)
You are persistent, Dovahkiin. Pruzah ol aar. A fine slave you would have made. Pruzah ol aar = “good as (a) slave” (Alduin, 000EDF49)
Means ‘good’ as in ‘well’ (‘a good day’, ‘well fought’), not ‘morally good’. See instead kul.
n. armor; hide, scales, plating, any outward defense; defense, protection
Mul qah diiv! Strength armor wyrm! (Dragon Aspect Shout)

Het ont kriist Miraak, wo ahtiid ok sahvot ol Qah, spaan naal Deyra fah ok unslaad midun. Here once stood Miraak, who wore his faith as Armor, shielded by the Daedra for his unending loyalty. (Word Wall for Qah, Dragon Aspect)
Given its role in the Dragon Aspect Shout, may better refer to a dragon’s scales or hide; any outward defense or protection.
v. to vanquish; to eliminate; to deny, resist n. vanquishment; elimination; denial, resistance
Sahrot thur qahnaraan! The mighty overlord is vanquished! (Dragon, 0009E075)
There are many hungers it is better to deny than to feed. … Discipline against the lesser aids in qahnaar... denial of the greater. (Paarthurnax, 0003F9E2)

Nau daar revak golt drey Freda zahrahmiik ek Laas, ful tol ek pogaan kiir filok, ahrk osos sul qahnaar ek hokoron. On this sacred ground did Freda sacrifice her Life, so that her many children might escape, and some day vanquish her enemies. (Word Wall for Laas, Aura Whisper)
Primarily means ‘to defeat in battle’. Can also mean ‘to eliminate or resist’ a thought or desire, as though in a mental struggle.

My claws have rended the flesh of innumerable foes, but I have never once been felled on the field of battle. I therefore honor-name you Qahnaarin, or Vanquisher in your tongue. (Durnehviir, 0201156B)
Used as a formal title for someone who has defeated a worthy opponent (esp. a dragon) in battle.
From Qahnaar ‘to vanquish’. -in may be a distinct suffix or the word in ‘master’, forming ‘master of vanquishing.
You have it. The Kel - the Elder Scroll. Tiid kreh... qalos. Time shudders at its touch. (Paarthurnax, 000C64EC)

Meaning may be closer to ‘presence’ than ‘physical touch’. Paarthurnax’s pause (as though searching for the right word) may also indicate this word’s meaning is more complex, perhaps related to time or the Elder Scrolls in an as of yet unknown way.
May derive from los, present tense conjugation of kos ‘to be’.
Occurs only in the compound word qethsegol ‘stone’, lit. ‘bone of the earth’.

Paarthurnax’s dialogue (‘There is no question. You are doom-driven … The very bones of the earth are at your disposal.’, 000C64EC) may indicate that the dragon word for ‘bone’ connotates a root or source of power. Dragon bones persist even after death, connotating something that is permanent or everlasting.
Stone (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)

Nafni wahlaan qethsegol bormahii vahrukt, Rognvald, wen Zii fen mahfaeraak aak ok brod, ahrk folook ok hokoron. Nafni raised this stone for his father, Rognvald, whose Spirit will forever guide his clan, and haunt his enemies. (Word Wall for Zii, Become Ethereal)

Common in the Word Wall memorials. May be a formal word that specifically refers to large, commemorative stones, or metaphorically ‘the earth itself’, whereas the general word golz ‘stone’ can refer to any stone or rock.
Se compound of qeth ‘bone’ and gol ‘earth’, lit. ‘bone of the earth’.
Possibly related to the cosmological ‘Earth Bones’.
v. to bow; to submit n. bow, bowing; submission
Nust wo ni qiilaan fen kos duaan. Those who (do) not bow will be devoured. (Alduin, 000ED363)
To submit to a power, authority, or fate. Unknown if dragons physically bow. May have originally meant ‘to submit’ but taken by Nords to also mean ‘to bow’.
Not to be confused for the weapon ‘bow’ or the naval ‘bow’.
Strun bah qo! Storm wrath lightning! (Storm Call Shout)

Qethsegol vahrukiv sahsunaar do daniik Vundeheim, ag nahlaas naal Qo do Unslaad Krosis. This stone commemorates the villagers of doomed Vundeheim, burned alive by the Lightning of Unending Sorrow. (Word Wall for Qo, Storm Call)
Word of Power, connotates raw, natural power, fire, and destruction.
n. herald, harbinger, something that precedes a doom or fate

Faas ni Brendon do Dinok, fah rok los qolaas do moro, ahrk hin aak wah lot Sovngarde. Fear not the Specter of Death, for he is the herald of glory, and your guide to great Sovngarde. (Word Wall for Faas, Dismay)
True... But qostiid - prophecy - tells what may be, not what should be. Qostiid= prophecy (KWOWES-teed) (Paarthurnax, 0003F9E1)
Qostiid sahlo aak. Just because you can do a thing, does not always mean you should. a Qostiid sahlo aak. (“Prophecy is a weak guide”) (Paarthurnax, 0003F9E1)

Dragons are ‘specially... attuned to the flow of Time’ (Paarthurnax, 0003FA42), and regard qostiid with less reverence than mortals. Represents what may come to happen, not what should. Action for the sake of prophecy is not always right.
Related to tiid ‘time’. May also relate to qolaas ‘herald’.
Diil qoth zaam! Undead tomb slave!
Word of Power used by Durnehviir to summon undead allies. Closely associated with qeth ‘bone’, may be a more general word referring to any grave or place of burial where bones are kept.
Granite Hill (Book, Holdings of Jarl Gjalund)
Granite Hill - Quethsegol [sic] Ahrol - Three Farms and an Inn, just North of the Falkreath. A Market is Held here Weekly. (Book, Holdings of Jarl Gjalund)
Qethsegol ‘stone’ is misspelled likely due to the inexperience of the Jarl Gjalund’s scribe, who wrote the name phonetically. Location in modern Skyrim is unknown.
Raan mir tah! Animal allegiance pack! (Animal Allegiance Shout)

Qethsegol vahrukiv key Sarvirra, zok krin Raan alun wah fonaar odus frod, ahrk ofan ok sil fah ok drog. This stone commemorates the horse Sarvirra, the most courageous Animal ever to charge the snowy battlefields, and give his soul for his lord. (Word Wall for Raan, Animal Allegiance)

Word of Power in the Animal Allegiance Shout, can refer to any animal, wild or tamed, but typically not monstrous creatures. (See instead sunvaar ‘beast’.) Closely associated with Kaan “Kyne’ and the realms of nature.
May derive from rah ‘god’ given the Nords’ animal totem worship.
n. god, deity, divine spirit or entity

[The Elder Scroll] is an... artifact from outside time. It does not exist, but it has always existed. Rah wahlaan. They are...hmm... fragments of creation. Rah wahlaan = gods (of) creation, or creator gods. (Paarthurnax, 000BBEAA)
Likely a general term, though its exact definition is unknown. Unknown if rah can or cannot refer to dragons, Alduin, or the Daedra, or if it is exclusive to the Aedra.

Het nok Faal Vahlok, deinmaar do Dovahgolz ahrk aan Fus do unslaad rahgol ahrk vulom. Here lies The Guardian, keeper of the Dragonstone and a Force of eternal rage and darkness. (Word Wall for Fus, Unrelenting Force)
More formal than ruth ‘rage’, which is often used as an interjection.
Occurs only as a dragon priest name.
adj. angry adv. angrily v. to anger

Het nok kopraan do Wynjolf ahrk Wuld, wen viintaas tuz vey zeim lahvu do rahgron Ogiim. Here lies the body of Wynjolf the Whirlwind, whose shining blades cut through an army of angry Orcs. (Word Wall for Wuld, Whirlwind Sprint)
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
Possibly related to reyth ‘tree’, given the shape of rivers from a dragon’s-eye view.
v. to roar, cry (battle cry) n. roar, battle cry
Sahrot Thu'um, med aan tuz, vey zeim hokoron pah, ol fin Dovahkiin komeyt ok rein! Mighty Thu'um, like a blade, cut through enemies all, as the Dragonborn issued his roar! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
A dragon-link roar. Also pertains to the Thu’um.
Arngeir. Rek los Dovahkiin, Strundu'ul. Rek fen tinvaak Paarthurnax. Arngeir. She is Dragonborn, (the) Stormcrown. She will speak (to) Paarthurnax. (Einarth, 000B3981)

Het dir bruniik rek-grohiik Ulfeidr, kriid muz ahrk sunvaar, bruniik kinbok Sahqon Tah. Here died the savage she-wolf Ulfeidr, slayer of men and beasts, and savage leader of the Crimson Pack. (Word Wall for Tah, Animal Allegiance)
Het nok kopraan do Hela, Fahdon wah pah sivaas aar do Kaan. Aal rek siiv unahzaal praan ko Feykro do Hahnu.
Here lies the body of Hela, friend to all beasts and servant of Kyne. May she find eternal rest in the Forest of Dreams. (Word Wall for Kaan, Kyne’s Peace)
Used in hyphenated compounds (rek-grohiik ‘she-wolf’) to form feminine nouns. Rek has not been observed in use by dragons. As dragons are sexless, rek may be a Nordic invention.
v. to dominate; to rule n. domination, dominance; rule, reign
Dov wahlaan fah rel. Dragons were created for domination. (Paarthurnax, 0003C574)
Possibly from English ‘rule’. Featured in the dragon names Kruziikrel ‘ancient domination’ and Relonikiv ‘domination enlightenment’.
adj. sacred, hallowed, holy adv. sacredly, in a sacred manner n. sacredness, sanctity, holiness v. to sanctify, consecrate, hallow
This is the most sacred mountain in Skyrim. Zok revak strunmah. The great mountain of the world. (Paarthurnax, 0003FA3E)

Nau daar revak golt drey Freda zahrahmiik ek Laas, ful tol ek pogaan kiir filok, ahrk osos sul qahnaar ek hokoron. On this sacred ground did Freda sacrifice her Life, so that her many children might escape, and some day vanquish her enemies. (Word Wall for Laas, Aura Whisper)

May refer to places that have been touched by the gods (e.g. Kyne’s involvement with the Throat of the World). Unknown if it is strictly religious or if it can refer to anything held in reverence. Also unknown what dragons would consider ‘sacred’ given they themselves are divine.
Wo lost fron wah ney dov, ahrk fin reyliik do jul, voth aan suleyk wah ronit faal krein! Who was kin to both wyrm, and the races of man, with a power to rival the sun! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
May share suffix with ufiik ‘troll’ and grohiik ‘wolf’ that denotes people or creatures.
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
The Sadon Reyth (‘Gray Tree’’) is the name of a ship that the Five Hundred Companions sailed from Atmora to Skyrim in Songs of the Return.
Rii vaaz zol! Essence tear zombie! (Soul Tear Shout)

Word of Power, close synonyms with sil ‘soul’ and zii ‘spirit’. May reach deeper than either sil or zii, though still refers to a tangible and destructible thing. Unlike zii, does not connotate etherealness or permanency.
Ven Mul Riik! [Wind Strength Gale!] Alduin shouts his evil mist back across Sovngarde. (Alduin, 0005094B)
Word of Power used by Alduin to cast mist over Sovngarde; harnesses a strong and unstoppable wind.
adv. very, exceedingly, in a high degree adj. very (exact, particular)
Rinik vazah. An apt phrase. Rinik vazah = “very true” (Odahviing, 00048F0D)
And he is no fool. Ni mey, rinik gut nol. Far from it. Ni mey = “no fool”, Rinik gut nol = “very far from” (Paarthurnax, 000556DB )

Het mah tahrodiis tafiir Skorji Lun-Sinak, wen klov govey naal rinik hahkun rok togaat wah gahrot. Here fell the treacherous thief Skorji Leech-Fingers, whose head was removed by the very axe he was attempting to steal.
Primarily the adverb ‘very’ as in ‘very strong’. Occurs once in the Word Walls as an adjective meaning ‘very’ as in ‘the very same’.
Fus ro dah! Force balance push! (Unrelenting Force Shout)
You will release me - ro laan - if in return I promise to take you to Skuldafn and stop helping Alduin? Ro laan = balanced request (Odahviing, 000E16EE)
Word of Power in the Unrelenting Force Shout, hones and focuses raw force.
The phrase orin brit ro ‘a fully beautiful balance’ (0004DE36) is used to express irony.
He (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 0009C218) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
pron. he (third person singular, masculine or gender-neutral)

Ahrk fin zul, rok drey kod, nau tol morokei frod, rul lot Taazokaan motaad voth kein! And the Voice, he did wield, on that glorious field, when great Tamriel shuddered with war! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Rok funta koraav. He failed to see. (Paarthurnax, 0009C218)

Het nok Faal Vahlok, wo kron pogaas moro. Fah ok unslaad mid, rok aav dilon voth lot zin. Here lies the Guardian, who won much glory. For his eternal loyalty, he joins the dead with great honor. Become Ethereal (Word Wall for Mid, Battle Fury)

Pronunciation of /rɑk/ is atypical and should be avoided. May be a gender-neutral pronoun given that dragons are non-gendered, refer to themselves with rok, and as far as is known do not recognize the pronoun rek.
Meyz nu Ysmir, Dovahsebrom. Dahmaan daar rok. (You have) become now Ysmir, Dragon of the North. Remember these words. (Greybeards, 000C43AE)
Occurs only in the phrase dahmaan daar rok ‘remember these words’. May be archaic or formal in usage.

Not to be confused with the pronoun rok ‘he’. In-game Word Walls use rot, but the Prima Games official guide mistakenly lists rok. This may have been changed late in development after the dialogue was finished.

Het mah faasnu ronaan Undveld, aar, kriid grohiik, ahrk drog do Lot Nir. Here fell the fearless archer Undveld, servant, slayer of wolves, and lord of the Great Hunt. (Word Wall for Nir, Aura Whisper)

May share root with ronaaz ‘arrow’, ronax ‘regiment’, and ronit ‘rival’ pertaining to warfare. May also derive from an unattested compound ronah ‘archery’ (lit. ‘balanced fury’) with the noun suffix -aan.

Thoringar wahlaan qethsegol monii vahrukt, Noomi, wen dez los wah Aus nin do pogaan Ogiim ronaaz. Thoringar raised this stone for his daughter’s memory, Noomi, whose fate it was to Suffer the sting of many Orc arrows. (Word Wall for Aus, Marked for Death)

May share root with ronaan ‘archer’, ronax ‘regiment’, and ronit ‘rival’ pertaining to warfare. May also derive from an unattested compound ronah ‘archery’ (lit. ‘balanced fury’) with a z that indicates sharpness or pain as seen in faaz ‘pain’, iiz ‘ice’, kinzon ‘sharp’, tuz ‘blade’ and vaaz ‘to tear’.

Qethsegol vahrukiv Kendov se Ved Ronax, Sille nu yoriik pindaar se Sovngarde pah Ul. This stone commemorates the warriors of the Black Regiment, whose souls now march on the plains of Sovngarde for all Eternity. (Word Wall for Ul, Slow Time)

May share root with ronaan ‘archer’, ronax ‘regiment’, and ronit ‘rival’ pertaining to warfare. May also be a compound word of ro ‘balance’ and nax ‘cruelty’, a force that dispenses justice or punishment.
v. to rival, match, equal n. rival, match, equal, comparison
Wo lost fron wah ney dov, ahrk fin reyliik do jul, voth aan suleyk wah ronit faal krein! Who was kin to both wyrm, and the races of man, with a power to rival the sun! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Does not mean ‘rival’ as in ‘foe’ or ‘opponent’. Denotes someone or something that is equal.
May share root with ronaan ‘archer’, ronax ‘regiment’, and ronit ‘rival’ pertaining to warfare.
Rorik’s Steading (Book, Holdings of Jarl Gjalund)
Rorik's Steading - Rorikhofkah - A Small Farmstead in the Western Plains. Grain, Leather, Horses. (Book, Holdings of Jarl Gjalund)
Compound of the name Rorik with hofkah ‘house’.

Nonvul Bron, dahmaan daar rok do fin Fodiiz Bormah - Faas ni Brendon do Dinok, fah rok los qolaas do moro, ahrk hin aak wah lot Sovngarde. Noble Nord, remember these words of the Hoar Father - Fear not the Specter of Death, for he is the herald of glory, and your guide to great Sovngarde. (Word Wall for Faas, Dismay)
Primarily spoken word, compared to the written sik ‘rune/word’.
In-game Word Walls use the word rot, but the Prima Games official guide mistakenly lists rok. This may have been changed late in development.
Ah, I forget how little you know of the dov. Our names are always made up of three Rotmulaag - Words of Power. (Paarthurnax, 000D2CF3)
Knowing a Word of Power is to take its meaning into yourself. … Contemplate the meaning of a Rotmulaag. You will become closer to that Word, as it fills your inner self. (Paarthurnax, 000E8277)
A word that is part of a Shout. Any word may hypothetically become a rotmulaag but its deeper meaning must be understood.
v. to wander, rove, roam n. wanderings

Het mah Hrothmar, Bah Grohiik do bruniik pindaar. Aal ok sil rovaan Sovngarde mahfaeraak. Here fell Hrothmar, Wrath Wolf of the savage plains. May his soul wander Sovngarde forever. (Word Wall for Bah, Storm Call)
Does not connotate being lost; to travel freely.
v. to run (from), flee n. run, flight
Faas ru maar! Fear run terror! (Dismay Shout)
Het nok kopraan do sonaan Romerius, wo unt Ru nol osos gogil, nuz motmah. Here lies the body of the bard Romerius, who tried to Run from some goblins, but slipped. (Word Wall for Ru, Dismay)
To move in haste, esp. to flee from danger. Differs from bovul ‘to flee’ in that it does not necessarily connotate defeat or loss of hope.
Rul (special case, used only when the word is the first in the sentence) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
conj. when; at the time of, in the event that (used only at the beginning of sentences or phrases)

Ahrk fin zul, rok drey kod, nau tol morokei frod, rul lot Taazokaan motaad voth kein! And the Voice, he did wield, on that glorious field, when great Tamriel shuddered with war! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
See synonym fod ‘when’, which is used more generally. Was likely invented to avoid repetition between frod and fod in the Song of the Dragonborn.
n. rage interj. rage. curses, damn
Faas nu [sic], zini dein ruthi ahst vaal. Fear not, my honor holds my rage at bay. (Odahviing, 000E898C)
Faaz! Nah! … So this is how you defeated Alduin. Ruth... zu'u ni Alduin. “Pain, fury!” = “damn you!”, Zu'u ni Alduin = “I (am) not Alduin.” (Odahviing, 000D2D72, 000D2D73)
Ruth wah nivahriin joor! Rage/curses to (you) cowardly mortal! (Alduin, 000C64F1)
More common in speech than synonym rahgol ‘rage’, used as an interjection to express anger or frustration.

Wulfik wahlaan qethsegol judii vahrukt, Hrefna Ruvaak-Om, wen miin Diin sos do naan jul. Wulfik raised this stone in memory of his queen, Hrefna Raven-Hair, whose eyes could Freeze the blood of any man. (Word Wall for Diin, Frost Breath)
Used to mean ‘black’. Possibly associated with the cold or death.
Then (“ahrk ruz” = “and then”) (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adv. then, after which, next in time

Nuz aan sul, fent alok, fod fin vul dovah nok, fen kos nahlot mahfaeraak ahrk ruz! Paaz Keizaal fen kos stin nol bein Alduin jot! But a day, shall arise, when the dark dragon's lies, will be silenced forever and then! Fair Skyrim will be free from foul Alduin's maw! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
adj. gray adv. grayly n. gray, grayness v. to gray, make or become gray

Loknir Mal-Tu wahlaan qethsegol aarii vahrukt, bonaar Vakeeza, wo vaat Mir wah jun do Keizaal, ahrk dir ko sadon gravuun. Loknir Little-Hammer erected this stone in memory of his servant, humble Vakeeza, who swore Allegiance to the kings of Skyrim, and died in the gray autumn. (Word Wall for Mir, Animal Allegiance)
Shares ending -on with sahqon ‘crimson’ and yuvon ‘golden’.
The Sadon Reyth (‘Gray Tree’’) is the name of a ship that the Five Hundred Companions sailed from Atmora to Skyrim in Songs of the Return.
adj. graybearded adv. in the manner of a graybeard n. graybeard v. to age, to make or become graybearded

Modir fin Sadonvum wahlaan qethsegol zeymahii vahrukt Oskar, wen zul los sahlo ahrk ni sahrot Thu’um do ok brod. [Modir the Greybeard raised (this) stone (in) his brother’s memory, Oskar whose voice was weak and not (the) mighty Thu’um of his clan.] (Unused Word Wall for Zul, Throw Voice)
Respectful, connotes great age and wisdom.

Unknown whether this refers to a member of the Greybeards, or is more likely an adjective describing someone who is gray-bearded. Similar, better understood words such as wuth ‘old’ and onik ‘wise’ should be used instead when referring to age.
adj. phantom, phantomlike, illusory adv. in an illusory manner n. phantom; illusion v. to make or become illusory
Fiik lo sah! Mirror deceive phantom! (Phantom Form Shout)

Qethsegol vahrukiv sod do Siglif fin Vonun wo aam lot Keizaal ni ol kendov ko vu nuz ol sah ko suvulaan. [(This) stone commemorates (the) deeds of Siglif the Unseen, who served great Skyrim not as (a) warrior in dawn, but as (a) phantom in twilight.] (Unused Word Wall for Sah, Phantom Form)
Word of Power; false or unreal, typically ghostly or supernatural.
adj. weak; ineffective, poor adv. weakly; poorly n. weakness v. to weaken
Qostiid sahlo aak. Prophecy is a weak guide. (Paarthurnax, 0003F9E1)

Modir fin Gut wahlaan qethsegol zeymahii vahrukt, Oskar fin Mey, wen Zul los sahlo, ahrk ni sahrot Thu’um do ok brod. Modir the Far raised this stone for his brother, Oskar the Fool, whose Voice was weak, and not the mighty Thu’um of his clan. (Word Wall for Throw Voice)
Draal ni fah Drem, fah grik los hind do sahlo ahrk nivahriin. Pray not for Peace, for such is the wish of the weak and cowardly. (Word Wall for Drem, Kyne’s Peace)
Red (Book, Dragon Language: Myth No More) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. red adv. redly n. red; redness v. to redden

Brothi wahlaan qethsegol kulii vahrukt, Odrav Keyn-Haal, wo drun pogaas zin wah Brod Sahqo-Strunmah. Brothi raised this stone for her son Odrav, Anvil-Hand, who brought much honor to Clan Red-Mountain. (Word Wall for Haal, Disarm)

Aesa wahlaan qethsegol briinahii vahrukt, Thohild fin Toor, wen smoliin ag frin ol Sahqo Heim. Aesa raised this stone for her sister, Thohild the Inferno, whose passion burned hot as the Red Forge. (Word Wall for Toor, Inferno)
Possibly truncated from sahqon ‘crimson’ given that ending -on is also seen in the colors sadon ‘gray’ and yuvon ‘golden’; more likely that sahqon came first than sahqon being an extension of sahqo.
adj. crimson adv. in a crimson-like manner n. crimson v. to make or become crimson

Het dir bruniik rek-grohiik Ulfeidr, kriid muz ahrk sunvaar, bruniik kinbok Sahqon Tah. Here died the savage she-wolf Ulfeidr, slayer of men and beasts, and savage leader of the Crimson Pack. (Word Wall for Tah, Animal Allegiance)

Lungerd wahlaan qethsegol ahmulii vahrukt, Thorgrima, deinmaar do sahqon yolos, ahrk drog do Lah. Lungerd raised this stone in memory of her husband, Thorgrima, keeper of the crimson flame, and lord of Magicka. (Word Wall for Lah, Drain Vitality)
Associated with fire and magic, possibly also blood.
Shares ending -on with sadon ‘gray’ and yuvon ‘golden’. Possibly derived from sahqo ‘red’ but the reverse is more likely.
Mighty (Book, Songs of Skyrim) (Dialogue File, 0009E075) (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
adj. mighty; great, significant adv. mightily; greatly, significantly n. might; mightiness; significance v. to become or make mighty
Sahrot Thu'um, med aan tuz, vey zeim hokoron pah, ol fin Dovahkiin komeyt ok rein! Mighty Thu'um, like a blade, cut through enemies all, as the Dragonborn issued his roar! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Sahrot thur qahnaraan! The mighty overlord is vanquished! (Dragon, 0009E075)
You have won a mighty victory. Sahrot krongrah - one that will echo through all the ages of this world for those who have eyes to see. (Paarthurnax, 0009C212)
Possessing great strength or power, or great significance.
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.

Qethsegol vahrukiv sahsunaar do daniik Vundeheim, ag nahlaas naal Qo do Unslaad Krosis. This stone commemorates the villagers of doomed Vundeheim, burned alive by the Lightning of Unending Sorrow. (Word Wall for Qo, Storm Call)
v. to believe, have faith in n. faith; belief

Het ont kriist Miraak, wo ahtiid ok sahvot ol Qah, spaan naal Deyra fah ok unslaad midun. Here once stood Miraak, who wore his faith as Armor, shielded by the Daedra for his unending loyalty. (Word Wall for Qah, Dragon Aspect)
Unknown if strictly religious or if it may pertain to general trust and loyalty.
Possibly related to unattested word sav/saav ‘to save’ from saviik ‘savior’, or related to ov ‘to trust’.
v. to wait, await; to delay n. wait; delay
Alduin saraan hin sil ko Sovngarde! Alduin awaits your soul in Sovngarde! (Dragon, 000E1705)
Lingrah krosis saraan Strundu'ul, voth nid balaan klov praan nau. Long sorrowfully (has) waited the Stormcrown, with no worthy head to rest on. (Greybeards, 000C43AB)
Dovahkiin, vosaraan! Use Dragonrend before Alduin consumes you! Vosaraan = do not delay (Paarthurnax, 000C64F6)

Qethsegol vahrukiv Bhor fin Golah, wo praal het mulhaan ol Gol saraan onikiv, nunon wah meyz wuth sinon do onik. This stone commemorates Bhor the Stubborn, who sat here still as Earth awaiting enlightenment, only to become old instead of wise. (Word Wall for Gol, Bend Will)
Dovahkiin kos fin saviik do muz! Dragonborn, be the savior of men! (Book, Songs of Skyrim)
Appears to be used in reverence, but likely not religious in connotation.
Likely from an unattested word sav/saav meaning ‘to save’ with the suffix -iik seen also in wunduniik ‘wanderer’.
Of, should be used when new words are formed (POGGLE, p. 1097) (PrimaGames.com)
prep. of, originating from; belonging to

Qethsegol vahrukiv vur do Faal Vahlok, nonvul aar se dovah wen dez lost wah qahnaar tahrodiis Miraak. This stone commemorates the valor of the Guardian, noble servant of dragons whose fate it was to vanquish the treacherous Miraak. (Word Wall for Vur, Battle Fury)

Het mah sahrot konahrik Aaban, kiin se Klo se Alikr, praan nu denek Keizaal. Here fell the mighty warlord Aaban, born of the Sand of the Alik’r, at rest now in the soil of Skyrim. (Word Wall for Klo, Slow Time)

Used only to indicate origin or possession. See the more general word do ‘of/about’. Used to form compound words such as qethsegol ‘stone’ (lit. ‘bone of the earth’) and suleyksejun ‘realm’ (lit. ‘power of the king’).
Mid vur shaan! Loyal valor inspire! (Battle Fury Shout)

Nonvul Bron, mahfaeraak dahmaan sahrot Vahlok wen lot ahkrin shaan ney muz ahrk dovah. Noble Nord, forever remember the mighty Guardian whose great courage inspired both men and dragons. (Word Wall for Shaan, Battle Fury)
Word of Power, associated with bravery, courage, and spirit, esp. in battle.
Sun (Word of Power, see also Krein) (Fire Breath Shout) (Dialogue File, 000B89E4) (POGGLE, p. 1097)
Yol toor shul! Fire inferno sun! (FIre Breath Shout)
A gift, Dovahkiin. Shul. Understand Sun as the dov do. (Paarthurnax, 000B89E4)
Het mah Herfodr Shul-Kriid, sahrot konahrik do Lumnaar do Krent Hahnu. Here fell Herfodr Sun-Slayer, mighty warlord of the Valley of Broken Dreams. (Word Wall for Shul, Fire Breath)
Word of Power, associated with daylight. Refers to the light and fire of the sun. Distinct from synonym krein, which more closely refers to the heavenly body itself (Magnus).

Het mah siigonis Neivaan wo wundun Gut nol hofkiin dir voth zin ko ahmik do Zeymahzin. [Here fell (the) lizard Nievaan, who travelled Far from home (to) die with honor in service of (the) Companions.] (Unused Word Wall for Gut, Throw Voice)
Originally means ‘lizard’ but also used to refer to Argonians, likely not derogatory.
v. to find; to encounter; to gain, come to possess n. find, finding
Hind siiv Alduin? (You) wish to find Alduin? (Odahviing, 00048F02)
Nivahriin muz fent siiv nid aaz het. Cowardly men shall find no mercy here. (Morokei, 00080103)

Het nok Yngnavar Gaaf-Kodaav, wo drey Yah moro nau Frod do Krosis, nuz sinon siiv dinok ahrk dukaan. Here lies Yngnavar Ghost-Bear, who did Seek glory on the Battlefield of Sorrows, but instead found death and dishonor. (Word Wall for Yah, Aura Whisper)

Het nok kopraan do Hela, Fahdon wah pah sivaas aar do Kaan. Aal rek siiv unahzaal praan ko Feykro do Hahnu. Here lies the body of Hela, friend to all beasts and servant of Kyne. May she find eternal rest in the Forest of Dreams. (Word Wall for Kaan, Kyne’s Peace)
Means ‘to locate’, but primarily used to mean ‘to encounter’ (‘to find death’) or ‘to gain or come to possess’ (‘to find one’s courage’). Likely from English ‘seek’.
Attested only in the PrimaGames.com list.
Alduin saraan hin sil ko Sovngarde! Alduin awaits your soul in Sovngarde! (Dragon, 000E1705)

Het mah Hrothmar, Bah Grohiik do bruniik pindaar. Aal ok sil rovaan Sovngarde mahfaeraak. Here fell Hrothmar, Wrath Wolf of the savage plains. May his soul wander Sovngarde forever. (Word Wall for Bah, Storm Call)
Pruzaan Zun ko Keizaal los hahdrim do dwiin-sil kendov. The best Weapon in Skyrim is the mind of a steel-souled warrior. (Word Wall for Zun, Disarm)

Qethsegol vahrukiv key Sarvirra, zok krin Raan alun wah fonaar odus frod, ahrk ofan ok sil fah ok drog. This stone commemorates the horse Sarvirra, the most courageous Animal ever to charge the snowy battlefields, and give his soul for his lord. (Word Wall for Raan, Animal Allegiance)

Specifically refers to souls in the afterlife. Generally should not be used in reference to dragons. Contrast with zii ‘spirit’ which more closely refers to living souls (such as the soul of a living person or dragon).

From English ‘soul’. Refers to literal souls, but also used to refer to character or nature (dwiin-sil ‘steel-souled’) or one’s life (ofan ok sil ‘to give his soul’). Not to be confused with the close homophone ziil ‘your spirit’.
Bahloki nahkip sillesejoor. My hunger has been fed by mortal souls. (Alduin, 000CDDF1)
He has travelled to Sovngarde to regain his strength, devouring the sillesejoor... the souls of the mortal dead. (Odahviing, 00048F05)
Refers to mortal souls in the afterlife.
